content: New Hampshire Senate Passes Marriage Equality The New Hampshire Senate approved a bill on Wednesday that would legalize same-sex marriage. The 13-11 vote mirrors the House's similarly close vote of 186-179 in March. Because the senate voted on a bill that has been amended since the house voted on it, HB 436 will return back to the house for a third reading. The senate version removed gender-specific language. Gov. John Lynch has expressed his preference for the same-sex civil unions already legal in New Hampshire. A poll released earlier this week shows that 55% of New Hampshire voters support marriage for same-sex couples, while 39% are opposed. More at >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid81229.asp This message has been edited. Last edited by: IHAWKER, Fri 29 May 2009 07:42 PM

title: UPDATE: New Hampshire Senate Passes Marriage Equality

content: New Hampshire Votes on Marriage The New Hampshire house will consider marriage-equality legislation today, after the senate approved the measure last Thursday. Marriage-equality legislation passed the house in March by a vote of 186-179, but the chamber must now consider whether to concur with the amended legislation that passed the senate by a vote of 13-11. The amendments to the legislation recognize the distinction between civil and religious marriage, and allow couples applying for a marriage license to continue to select the terms “husband” and “wife,” or opt for the new gender-neutral term “spouse.” Report at ... >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid82567.asp

content: aw, c'mon. The anticipation is deliciously intense. First, Maine, then Washington D.C. and now this? I've been beaming all week.

title: UPDATE: New Hampshire Senate Passes Marriage Equality

content: N.H. Compromises on Marriage Bill May 29, 2009 New Hampshire house and senate negotiators agreed on new language in the state's same-sex marriage bill late Friday, reports The Boston Globe . The bill will be voted on Wednesday, the next time the legislature convenes. The new version specifies that all religious organizations have exclusive control over their religious doctrines, policies, and beliefs on marriage. Last week, the house turned down a revised same-sex marriage bill that included religious exemptions mandated by Gov. John Lynch. The senate had passed the revised bill and the full legislature had passed original versions of the bill earlier this year. The new language does not differ much from the earlier version -- churches are still exempt from providing insurance and other benefits and services to same-sex partners of employees. Governor Lynch reportedly agrees to the compromise. More at ... >>>http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid87241.asp
